pageData.text: This investigation introduces the functional properties of nervous tissue. The student will observe the speed at which nervous tissue responds to stimuli by performing <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> tests on a test subject. The nature of stimuli (touch, heat, and cold) will also be explored by the testing of general cutaneous (skin) sensations on the test subject.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Patellar (Knee Jerk) Reflex - 5 minutes
Activity 2: Calcaneal (Ankle Jerk, Achilles) Reflex - 5 minutes
Activity 3: Plantar Reflex - 5 minutes
Activity 4: Biceps Reflex - 5 minutes
Activity 5: Triceps Reflex - 5 minutes
Activity 6: Stimulus Sensitivity Testing - 15 minutes
Activity 7: Two-Point Discrimination - 15 minutes
Activity 8: Temperature Sensation - 15 minutes

pageData.text:
Note for students:
The sensory and tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If the results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: Describe the cellular composition and function of nervous tissue.
Explain what a <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arc</button> is and how it works.
Perform and interpret common clinical tests of nervous function.

pageData.text: Although pain is an uncomfortable, sometimes chronic, part of our lives, it is an .invaluable sensation that allows us to maintain homeostasis. Pain and other stimuli, such as temperature and pressure, are perceived by <button class='glossary-text'>neurons</button> throughout the body - most notably the skin, which interacts directly with our environment. This sensory information is passed to the <button class='glossary-text'>central nervous system (CNS)</button>, which initiates a response in other parts of the body, in a <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arc</button>. For example, placing your hand on a hot stove will send a pain signal to the spinal cord which will signal to the affected hand to pull back. But what would your life be like if your body could not complete such reflex arcs?

Patients with hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy (HSAN) type IV are unable to do just that. They cannot feel pain and often cannot perceive differences in temperature. HSAN is a genetic disorder in which the <button class='glossary-text'>nerves</button> responsible for transmitting information about pain, temperature, and pressure do not function properly due to a mutation<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. While it may seem like a superpower to live a life without pain, we rely on pain to learn about dangers in our environment, especially as children, and to inform us when our bodies require medical attention.

Reference1Herbert, C. by S. (2017, August 22). Meet the boy who can't feel pain. Health24.
https://www.news24.com/health24/Medical/Genetics/News/meet-the-boy-who-cant-feel-pain-20170822

pageData.desc: A woman in pain holding her neck and shoulders.
pageData.altText: A woman in pain holding her neck and shoulders.

pageData.text: The nervous system has two major divisions: the , consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the , consisting of a network of that extend throughout the body. The organs of the nervous system are composed largely of nervous tissue. Two major cell types are present in nervous tissue: and . Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses, whereas glia (also called glial cells or neuroglia) provide structural and metabolic support for neurons. A typical neuron has three major components (see Figure 1):

text: The <button class='glossary-text'>cell body</button> (or soma) houses the nucleus and most of the organelles.
<button class='glossary-text'>Dendrites</button> convey impulses toward the cell body.
A single <button class='glossary-text'>axon</button> conveys impulses away from the cell body.

pageData.text: Although a neuron will have only one axon, that axon may have multiple branches. Some axons are enclosed within an insulating <button class='glossary-text'>myelin sheath</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a motor neuron, showing multiple dendrites and a single axon with a myelin sheath extending from the cell body, branching, and forming neuromuscular junctions with muscle at its terminals

pageData.text: Communication occurs between a <button class='glossary-text'>neuron</button> and its target cell at a structure called a <button class='glossary-text'>synapse</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>neuromuscular junctions</button> shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button> are synapses between a motor neuron of the brain or spinal cord and skeletal muscle cells that contract in response to stimulation. Figure 2 depicts a chemical synapse, so called because a chemical signal is passed between the neuron, or <button class='glossary-text'>presynaptic cell</button>, and its target, the <button class='glossary-text'>postsynaptic cell</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>axon</button> terminal of the presynaptic cell contains synaptic vesicles filled with signaling molecules called neurotransmitters. When a <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> impulse reaches the axon terminal, voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane open and allow an influx of Ca<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup>. This results in the release of neurotransmitter molecules into the synaptic cleft, the narrow space between the axon terminal and the surface of the target cell. The neurotransmitter molecules diffuse across the cleft and bind to receptors in the membrane of the postsynaptic cell. The receptors are ligand-gated channels that open and permit an influx of Na<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>, which triggers a response in the postsynaptic cell.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of signal transmission at a chemical synapse

pageData.question: Voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane open and allow an influx of calcium ions (Ca<sup class='bodySupscript'>2+</sup>), triggering the release of neurotransmitters, when a nerve impulse reaches which of the following neuron structures?

options.text: axon terminal
cell body
dendrite
myelin sheath
soma

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The axon terminal of the presynaptic cell contains synaptic vesicles filled with signaling molecules called neurotransmitters. When a nerve impulse reaches the axon terminal, voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane open and allow an influx of Ca2+ which triggers neurotransmitter release.

pageData.question: Which of the following would be considered the postsynaptic cell at a neuromuscular junction?

options.text: skeletal muscle
motor neuron
sensory neuron
spinal cord glial cell
red blood cell

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Neuromuscular junctions are intersections between motor neurons and muscle cells. At this type of synapse, the muscle cell is the postsynaptic, or target, cell.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses. Communication occurs between a neuron and its target cell at a structure called the synapse. Here, the electrical nerve impulse reaches the axon terminal of the presynaptic cell and triggers the release of chemicals called neurotransmitters, which travel across the synaptic cleft to the target cell, or postsynaptic cell, to generate a response. A neuromuscular junction is a synapse between a motor neuron of the brain or spinal cord and skeletal muscle cells that contract in response to stimulation.

img.alt: Figure 2: Diagram of signal transmission at a chemical synapse

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Neurons receive and transmit electrochemical signals called nerve impulses. Communication occurs between a neuron and its target cell at a structure called the synapse. Here, the electrical nerve impulse reaches the axon terminal of the presynaptic cell and triggers the release of chemicals called neurotransmitters, which travel across the synaptic cleft to the target cell, or postsynaptic cell, to generate a response. A neuromuscular junction is a synapse between a motor neuron of the brain or spinal cord and skeletal muscle cells that contract in response to stimulation.

img.alt: Figure 2: Diagram of signal transmission at a chemical synapse

pageData.text: There are two distinct types of nervous tissue:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Gray matter</button> is made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies; <button class='glossary-text'>dendrites</button>; and short, unmyelinated <button class='glossary-text'>axons</button>, together with <button class='glossary-text'>glia</button> and tiny blood vessels. In preserved but unstained specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears gray in color.

<button class='glossary-text'>White matter</button> is made up mainly of axons. It naturally appears white because the axons are sheathed in a fatty substance called myelin. This <button class='glossary-text'>myelin sheath</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>) is produced by certain glia.

pageData.text: Gray and <button class='glossary-text'>white matter</button> are present in both the CNS and PNS. In the brain, most of the <button class='glossary-text'>gray matter</button> is superficial and the white matter is deep. In the spinal cord, the arrangement is reversed—the white matter is superficial and the gray matter is deep. When viewed in cross section (see Figure 3), the spinal gray matter resembles a butterfly in shape; each of the “wings” is divided into a <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal horn</button>, or posterior horn, and a <button class='glossary-text'>ventral horn</button>, or anterior horn. (In the thoracic and upper lumbar regions, there is a third horn of gray matter located between the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> horns, known as the lateral horn.) Bundles of myelinated <button class='glossary-text'>axons</button> in the PNS are termed <button class='glossary-text'>nerves</button>, and collections of gray matter are called <button class='glossary-text'>ganglia</button>. In Figure 3, the spinal nerve associated with this segment of the spinal cord has two branches, called roots: a <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal root</button>, or posterior root, and a <button class='glossary-text'>ventral root</button>, or anterior root. Each plays a different role in communication between the CNS and the periphery.

Note: Dorsal, ventral, anterior, and are directional terms used in anatomical studies. Dorsal means “toward the belly,” and ventral means “toward the back.” Anterior means “toward the front of the body,” and posterior means “toward the back of the body.”

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A cross section of the spinal cord with key structures labeled

pageData.text: There are three different functional types of <button class='glossary-text'>neurons</button>.

1. are responsive to sensory stimuli. The cell bodies of most sensory neurons reside in PNS , such as the —the enlarged region of the adjacent to the spinal cord (see ). Their extend to the skin or other organs. Thus, sensory neurons send impulses from their receptive endings toward their cell bodies and from there down their to the CNS. Sensory neurons are often called to emphasize the direction of the impulses they carry toward the CNS.
  2. generate impulses that simulate muscle cells to contract. The axons of motor neurons with cell bodies in the of the spinal make up the of a spinal nerve. Motor neurons are also referred to as because they send impulses away from the CNS.
  3. , or association neurons, are located between sensory and motor neurons. They reside entirely within the CNS. Interneurons allow sensory information to undergo additional processing in the CNS to integrate sensory input with motor output. Interneurons are by far the most abundant type of .

pageData.subTitle: Reflexes
pageData.text: The nervous system is capable of rapid, transient responses to stimuli. The incredible speed of interactions between neurons and their target effectors (such as skeletal muscles) becomes apparent when examining reflexes, which are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. For instance, if you accidentally touch a hot object, you immediately jerk your hand away before you consciously perceive heat and pain. The cells involved in generating a reaction make up a .
There are two main groups of reflexes:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cranial reflexes</button> involve the brain and cranial nerves. Examples include the blink and gag reflexes.
<button class='glossary-text'>Spinal reflexes</button>, such as the patellar and plantar reflexes, involve the spinal cord and spinal nerves.

pageData.text: Figure 4 depicts one type of <button class='glossary-text'>spinal reflex</button> arc. Identify the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ventral roots</button> and the three types of <button class='glossary-text'>neurons</button>. Notice that the <button class='glossary-text'>axon</button> terminal of the afferent neuron <button class='glossary-text'>synapses</button> with an interneuron with a <button class='glossary-text'>cell body</button> located in the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal horn</button>. The next neuron in the <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arc</button> is the efferent neuron. It responds by generating its own impulse, which passes down its axon to a muscle cell, stimulating it to contract. This is an example of a <button class='glossary-text'>polysynaptic reflex arc</button>—it involves a synapse between an afferent neuron and an <button class='glossary-text'>interneuron</button>, and an additional synapse between the interneuron and an efferent neuron. However, some reflex arcs are simpler. In a <button class='glossary-text'>monosynaptic reflex arc</button>, the afferent neuron synapses directly with the efferent neuron, without an interneuron situated between them.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the parts of a polysynaptic reflex arc activated in response to contact with a hot object, resulting in arm withdrawal

pageData.question: Blinking and gagging are examples of what kind of reflex?

options.text: cranial reflex
spinal reflex
motor reflex
monosynaptic reflex
postsynaptic reflex

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cranial reflexes are controlled by cranial nerves, not the spinal cord, and generally occur in the face or head region.

pageData.question: Which of the following scenarios is most closely associated with a polysynaptic reflex arc?

options.text: Adrienne suppresses the urge to gag while eating unpleasant food.
Molly reaches for her foot after stubbing a toe.
Justine smiles back at a child smiling at her.
Rita blinks and begins to tear up when cigarette smoke enters her eyes.
Bella unconsciously scratches her ear when she has poor cards in a poker game.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In a polysynaptic reflex arc, the communication between an afferent neuron and an efferent neuron is mediated by an interneuron. This allows the reflex to be suppressed.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The nervous system is capable of rapid responses to stimuli. The incredible speed of interactions between neurons and their target effectors (such as skeletal muscles) becomes apparent when examining reflexes, which are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. There are two main groups of reflexes. Some reflexes, such as those that take place in the face or head region, involve the brain and cranial nerves. Others involve the spinal cord and spinal nerves. Reflexes can also be described by their complexity. A polysynaptic reflex arc involves a synapse between an afferent neuron and an interneuron, and an additional synapse between the interneuron and an efferent neuron. For example, if an object unexpectedly touches the eye, the blink reflex involuntarily closes the eyelid as a protective measure. However, the interneuron of the blink reflex arc makes it possible to consciously keep the eyelid open when an object such as a contact lens touches the surface of the eyeball. In contrast, a monosynaptic reflex arc is simpler: the afferent neuron synapses directly with the efferent neuron without an interneuron situated between them.

img.alt: A diagram of the pupil reflex pathway. Light hits the cornea of one eye and triggers a signal from the pupil to the brain, and then from the brain to the pupil of the other eye via the ciliary ganglion.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The nervous system is capable of rapid responses to stimuli. The incredible speed of interactions between neurons and their target effectors (such as skeletal muscles) becomes apparent when examining reflexes, which are involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli. There are two main groups of reflexes. Some reflexes, such as those that take place in the face or head region, involve the brain and cranial nerves. Others involve the spinal cord and spinal nerves. Reflexes can also be described by their complexity. A polysynaptic reflex arc involves a synapse between an afferent neuron and an interneuron, and an additional synapse between the interneuron and an efferent neuron. For example, if an object unexpectedly touches the eye, the blink reflex involuntarily closes the eyelid as a protective measure. However, the interneuron of the blink reflex arc makes it possible to consciously keep the eyelid open when an object such as a contact lens touches the surface of the eyeball. In contrast, a monosynaptic reflex arc is simpler: the afferent neuron synapses directly with the efferent neuron without an interneuron situated between them.

img.alt: A diagram of the pupil reflex pathway. Light hits the cornea of one eye and triggers a signal from the pupil to the brain, and then from the brain to the pupil of the other eye via the ciliary ganglion.

pageData.text: Since <button class='glossary-text'>interneurons</button> are not always necessary for a <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arc</button>, what function do they serve? Interneurons facilitate communication between components of the reflex arc and other parts of the CNS, such as the brain. The brain can consciously perceive and even anticipate incoming sensory information and may even be able to override and inhibit the motor component of the <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button>. For example, if an object unexpectedly touches the eye, the blink reflex involuntarily closes the eyelid as a protective measure. However, the interneuron of the blink reflex arc makes it possible to consciously keep the eyelid open when an object such as a contact lens touches the surface of the eyeball.

Doctors often test patients’ reflexes because an abnormal reflex can indicate nervous system malfunction. For example, the patellar, calcaneal tendon, biceps, and triceps tests in Activities 1, 2, 4, and 5 are all tests of proper function of the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal root</button> <button class='glossary-text'>ganglia</button> for their respective spinal <button class='glossary-text'>nerves</button>. Absence of muscle contraction when the stimulus (a light tap with a percussion hammer) is applied might indicate disease or injury to those nerves. The plantar reflex (tested in Activity 3), evoked by running the hammer along the sole of the foot, is normally flexion (curling) of the toes. The opposite reaction—extending and spreading the toes—may indicate an upper <button class='glossary-text'>motor neuron</button> (i.e., brain) lesion affecting the lower extremity being tested.

pageData.subTitle: General Sensations
pageData.text: The skin is the largest sensory organ of the body. The skin has many receptor sites for cutaneous sensations (from the Latin cutis, meaning “skin”) and is sensitive to many kinds of stimuli, including touch, pressure, temperature, and pain. The ability to perceive each of these sensations is equal to the number of receptors per unit area; this varies depending on the location of the body surface. A is the area on the skin that activates a . Receptive fields may be small and numerous or large and overlapping. Areas of the body such as the tongue, lips, and fingertips contain higher receptor densities with smaller receptive fields and can therefore sense stimuli more accurately. Areas such as the back, arms, thighs, and calves have fewer receptors per unit area and larger receptive fields. These areas have lower sensitivity and/or discrimination ability.

Medical professionals often test for the presence or absence of sensation using <button class='glossary-text'>monofilament</button>—a single, synthetic, untwisted filament that is often made of nylon. Monofilament is primarily used for testing sensation thresholds of patients who may be at risk for diabetic foot ulceration, degenerative <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> disease, and similar ailments. The premise behind monofilament testing is that an increased diameter of monofilament would require a larger force to bend it when applied to the surface of the skin. Medical monofilaments are calibrated and assigned numbers that correspond to their diameter. Monofilaments with higher numbers are stiffer (due to their greater diameter) and deliver more buckling stress force. The 5.07 monofilament is the accepted medical standard for sensation measurement, yielding 10 grams of force when sufficient pressure is applied so the monofilament just barely bends against the surface of the skin.

The (or two-point threshold test) is another method of measuring the sensitivity of an area of the skin to touch. The two-point threshold is defined as the smallest amount of separation between two points touching the skin that produces two distinct sensations of touch. For two distinct points to be perceived, a non-stimulated receptor must reside between the two stimulated receptors. When a two-point stimulus, such as the Carolina® two-point discriminator, is no longer detected as two points of contact on the skin but rather feels like a single point, the two-point threshold has been crossed. In areas of the skin that are more sensitive, the size is smaller, and it is therefore easier to sense two points that are closer together.

Cutaneous thermoreceptors are free <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> endings that respond to particular ranges of temperatures and changes within those ranges. Separate locations on the skin are either sensitive to hot and cold or are not sensitive to temperature at all. Cold receptors are sensitive to decreasing temperature, and heat receptors signal information about increasing temperature. Temperature sensitivity is not uniformly distributed. Cold receptors are unevenly distributed throughout the dermis and subcutaneous layer of the skin and are activated by temperatures from 10° C to about 30° C (50° F to 86° F). Warmth receptors are deeper and less numerous than cold receptors. They become active above 30° C (about 86° F) with a peak response around 43° C (109.4° F). Free nerve endings within these temperature ranges detect hot and cold sensations, but further temperature increases or decreases activate pain receptors. Therefore, extremely hot temperatures above 45° C (113° F) or cold temperatures below 10° C (50° F) activate pain receptors to warn of potential harm. Temperature receptors also show some adaptation over time as the body adjusts to a particular temperature.

In this investigation, you will explore the properties of nervous tissue by testing reflexes in response to various stimuli. You will also apply stimuli to the skin using a medical <button class='glossary-text'>monofilament</button>, a two-point discriminator, and an aluminum temperature probe. The data collected will allow you to draw conclusions about the nature of <button class='glossary-text'>reflex arcs</button> and the distribution and sensitivity of sensory receptors in the skin.

pageData.question: Medical professionals can test for the presence or absence of sensation using a thin piece of nylon called a monofilament. What is significant about the diameter of the monofilament during such testing?

options.text: The greater the diameter the more pressure is applied to the patient’s skin.
The greater the diameter the less pressure is applied to the patient’s skin.
The greater the diameter the more sensitive the testing area on the patient.
The greater the diameter the larger the required testing area on the patient.
The greater the diameter the smaller the required testing area on the patient.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A monofilament is primarily used for testing sensation thresholds of patients who may be at risk for conditions such as diabetic foot ulceration. If a larger monofilament is required to generate sensation in the test area, the patient has decreased sensitivity in that area.

pageData.question: In a two-point threshold test, which of the following results best describes a patient with decreased touch sensitivity?

options.text: The patient feels one point of contact with the discriminator spaced widely apart.
The patient feels two points of contact with the discriminator spaced widely apart.
The patient feels two points of contact with the discriminator spaced close together.
The patient feels one point of contact when the discriminator is removed from the skin.
The patient feels two points of contact in another location of the body during the test.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: For two distinct points to be perceived during a two-point threshold test, a non-stimulated receptor must reside between the two stimulated receptors. Therefore, a patient who feels only one point of contact while the discriminator is spaced widely apart has low touch sensitivity in the tested area.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Monofilaments (left) are calibrated and assigned numbers that correspond to their diameter. Those with higher numbers are stiffer (due to their greater diameter) and deliver more buckling stress force. The premise behind this testing is that an increased diameter of monofilament would require a larger force to bend it when applied to the surface of the skin, thus applying more pressure to the test area. Another method of testing for sensitivity is the two-point threshold test. When a two-point stimulus, such as the Carolina<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> two-point discriminator (right), is no longer detected as two points of contact on the skin but rather feels like a single point, the two-point threshold has been crossed.

img.alt: A wire-like piece of clear plastic monofilament attached to a tab of paper.
A two-point discriminator being applied to an open palm.

hintData.body: Monofilaments (left) are calibrated and assigned numbers that correspond to their diameter. Those with higher numbers are stiffer (due to their greater diameter) and deliver more buckling stress force. The premise behind this testing is that an increased diameter of monofilament would require a larger force to bend it when applied to the surface of the skin, thus applying more pressure to the test area. Another method of testing for sensitivity is the two-point threshold test. When a two-point stimulus, such as the Carolina<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> two-point discriminator (right), is no longer detected as two points of contact on the skin but rather feels like a single point, the two-point threshold has been crossed.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.  Before starting any activities, you will need to locate a test subject. In Activities 1-5, you will perform five different reflex tests. conduct a stimulus sensitivity test for three different body locations. In Activity 6, you will need to conduct stimulus sensitivity test. 3 body locations tested?  If so, yes go forward if not, no go back. In Activity 7, you will conduct two-point discrimination tests on five locations, for three trials at each location. Then, you will calculate the average two-point threshold value at each location. In Activity 8, you will conduct cold sensation tests on three locations. Then, you will conduct warm sensation tests on three locations.

In Activity 7, you will conduct two-point discrimination tests on five locations, for three trials at each location. Then, you will calculate the average two-point threshold value at each location. In Activity 8, you will conduct cold sensation tests on three locations. Then, you will conduct warm sensation tests on three locations.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Reflexes and General Sensation investigation (item number 580526) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.altText: gloves symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. The use of gloves is optional while working with your test subject; however, be sure to wash your hands thoroughly before and after, regardless of whether gloves are worn. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

This investigation requires a short period of physical activity by the test subject. If the test subject is not in good health or is unable to perform these activities, please seek another test subject or alert the course instructor.

When striking the test subject with the Taylor <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> percussion hammer, a light tap should be sufficient to evoke a reflex response. Excessive force may result in <button class='glossary-text'>nerve</button> injury.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>When testing for heat receptors with the aluminum temperature probe, do not use boiling water. Hot tap water is sufficient to warm the probe.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Be aware that the results obtained in this investigation cannot substitute for a thorough exam by a trained health-care professional.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: The tissue in the central nervous system (CNS) can be divided into gray matter and white matter. Which of the following is responsible for giving white matter its color?

options.text: myelin
glia
nuclei
blood vessels
ganglia

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes bundles of myelinated axons in the peripheral nervous system (PNS)?

options.text: nerves
tracts
nuclei
ganglia
glia

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is the presynaptic neuron of a neuromuscular junction?

options.text: motor neuron
skeletal muscle cell
sensory neuron
dorsal root ganglion
interneuron

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the main function of an interneuron in a reflex arc?

options.text: to facilitate additional processing of signals received by the central nervous system
to take up unused neurotransmitter molecules from the synapse
to insulate the axon of the presynaptic neuron
to perceive stimuli from the environment
to convey impulses to muscles and glands in response to sensory information

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the functional difference between the dorsal root (and dorsal root ganglion) and the ventral root of a spinal nerve?

options.text: The dorsal root conveys sensory impulses; the ventral root conveys motor impulses.
The dorsal root receives sensory impulses; the ventral root initiates sensory impulses.
The dorsal root receives motor impulses; the ventral root initiates motor impulses.
The dorsal root sends signals faster than the ventral root.
The dorsal root processes reflexes; the ventral root processes voluntary movement.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the reason a doctor might conduct a reflex test on a patient?

options.text: to test for proper nerve function
to test for muscle degeneration
to test for learning disorders
to test for memory disorders
to test for skin sensitivity

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is true about skin’s ability to perceive touch?

options.text: Sensitive areas of skin have smaller receptive fields.
Sensitive areas of skin have larger receptive fields.
Sensitive areas of skin have high two-point thresholds.
Sensitive areas of skin do not have a two-point threshold.
Skin sensitivity is uniform for the entire human body.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the distribution of temperature receptors in the human body?

options.text: Both cold and warmth receptors are unevenly distributed.
Cold receptors are in the epidermis; warmth receptors are in all skin layers.
Cold receptors are deeper in the skin than warmth receptors.
Cold and warmth receptors are in the dermis but there are more warmth receptors.
Cold receptors are in the extremities; warmth receptors are throughout the body.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety warnings is associated with the Taylor reflex percussion hammer provided for this investigation?

options.text: When striking the test subject with the hammer, do not use excessive force.
When striking the test subject with the hammer, use only the flat end.
Ask the test subject for permission prior to each strike with the hammer.
Do not use the hammer on a test subject who has recently exercised.
The hammer is to be used on inanimate objects only, never the test subject.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety warnings applies to the temperature sensation tests you will conduct in Activity 8?

options.text: Use hot, but not boiling, water to warm the temperature probe.
Do not use ice to cool the temperature probe.
Provide a fan or cool washcloth for the test subject to avoid overheating.
Sanitize the temperature probe with isopropyl alcohol between uses.
Be prepared to catch the test subject if they become dizzy during the tests.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
The test subject should prepare by wearing clothing that exposes the feet, knees, and elbows.
Clear the work area, and wash your hands.
Read the instructions.
Obtain all necessary materials.
After completing each activity, you may wish to switch places with the test subject and repeat the activity.
In Activity 1, you will observe the patellar (knee jerk) reflex in the test subject using the percussion hammer.

typeBefore.text: Caution: In this and the following test activities, limit the amount of force applied with the percussion hammer. Excessive force may result in damage.

pageData.text: Have the test subject sit in a chair or on a bench, facing you. The lower leg should hang freely off the edge. If the seat is not high enough, the test subject may cross the leg to be tested over the opposite leg, keeping both legs relaxed.
Locate the patella (kneecap) on the subject’s right leg.
Find the patellar tendon just below the middle of the patella. It will feel soft in comparison to the bony patella.

Use the pointed end of the percussion hammer to tap gently on the subject’s patellar tendon (see Figure 5). Observe the reflex. Alternatively, you may wish to place your thumb over the patellar tendon and strike the thumb with the hammer instead. Reflex activity will result in extension of the subject’s lower leg. Record the result in Data Table 1.
Repeat the procedure for your subject’s left leg, and record the result in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: The patellar reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer
pageData.altText: Figure 5: The patellar reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will observe the calcaneal (ankle jerk, Achilles) reflex in the test subject using the percussion hammer.

pages.title: Calcaneal (Ankle Jerk, Achilles) Reflex (3 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
   Calcaneal (Ankle Jerk, Achilles) Reflex (3 steps)

pageData.text: Have your test subject sit on a chair or bench with the right foot suspended from the edge. Support the subject’s right foot. Alternatively, the subject can lie back or even kneel on a chair while you support the right foot.

Use the flat edge of the percussion hammer to strike the subject’s right Achilles tendon just above the heel on the back of the leg (see Figure 6). Observe the , which is plantar flexion of the foot. Record the result in Data Table 1.
Hint: If you hold your hand under the ball of the foot, you may feel the reflex even if it is hard to see.
Have the subject reverse leg positions. Support the subject’s left foot. Strike the subject’s left Achilles tendon just above the heel on the back of the leg, and record the result in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: The calcaneal reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer
pageData.altText: Figure 6: The calcaneal reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will observe the plantar <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> in the test subject using the percussion hammer.
Have the test subject extend the right foot toward you. Either support the heel yourself or allow the subject to use another chair for heel support.

Slide the handle of the percussion hammer along the bottom of the bare right foot (see Figure 7), moving from the heel up the lateral side of the foot and then across the ball of the foot to the big toe, observing the activity of the toes. The normal reflex in adults is flexion. In a very young child (up to 2 years old), the expected result is the extension of the big toe, known as the Babinski reflex. Record the result in Data Table 1.
Note: If the test subject experiences discomfort from the hammer handle, the pointed end of the rubber head may be used instead.
Repeat the procedure with the left foot, and record the result in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: The plantar reflex test being performed using the handle of a percussion hammer
pageData.altText: Figure 7: The plantar reflex test being performed using the handle of a percussion hammer

pageData.text: In Activity 4, you will observe the biceps <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> in the test subject using the percussion hammer.
Have the test subject sit in a chair or on a bench with the arms relaxed.

Place your thumb on the biceps tendon of one of the subject’s arms (see Figure 8), and strike your thumbnail with the percussion hammer. (Either side of the hammer may be used since the force will be transmitted through your thumb to the test subject. Use the side that feels most comfortable.) The expected is flexion of the forearm. Observe the reflex, and record the result in Data Table 1.
Repeat with the test subject’s other arm, and record the result in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: The biceps reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer
pageData.altText: Figure 8: The biceps reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer

pageData.text: In Activity 5, you will observe the triceps <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> in the test subject using the percussion hammer.
Have the test subject sit in a chair or on a bench with the arms relaxed.

Hold one of the subject’s arms, and strike the triceps tendon directly with the percussion hammer (see Figure 9). Alternatively, you may place your thumb over the triceps tendon and strike your thumbnail with the hammer. Observe the , which is expected to be an extension of the forearm, and record the result in Data Table 1.
Repeat the procedure with the subject’s other arm, and record the result in Data Table 1.

pageData.desc: The triceps reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer
pageData.altText: Figure 9: The triceps reflex test being performed using a percussion hammer

pageData.text: In Activity 6, you will conduct stimulus sensitivity tests on the skin of the test subject’s hand (back and palm) and forearm using a <button class='glossary-text'>monofilament</button>.
Use the ink pad and the grid stamp to stamp the grid on the back of the test subject’s hand, the palm of the hand, and the inside of the forearm.

Note: The ink is washable and will come off very easily with water; it will also smudge very easily. Be sure to apply pressure evenly so that all the grids in the stamp transfer onto the test subject’s skin. Note that the concavity of the palm may be difficult to imprint.
The test subject sits with eyes closed and the stamped hand motionless on a desk or table with the palm facedown. Begin with the grid on the back of the hand.

In one quadrant of the grid, gently touch each space with the medical <button class='glossary-text'>monofilament</button>. The monofilament should be held by its paper handle and touched lightly to a space on the test subject’s skin. The test subject reports whether they feel a stimulus.
Note: Touch the filament to the subject’s skin gently so that the monofilament just barely bends.
Record each time a stimulus is felt by the test subject by coloring in the corresponding space on the appropriate grid in the “Observations” section.
Repeat this activity, touching the other spaces on the grid, reporting the sensation, and recording the responses. Continue until all the spaces have been tested.

Repeat this procedure for the palm and forearm locations, and record the results in the appropriate grids. Remember that to analyze the data correctly, the results must be organized, complete, and recorded accurately.
Compare the results for the different test areas.
In Activity 7, you will conduct two-point discrimination tests on the skin of the test subject’s fingertip, palm, forearm, neck, and lower leg.
The test subject should sit with eyes closed and one hand palm up and motionless on a desk or table. Begin by testing the fingertip.

Start with the two points of the two-point discriminator touching each other. In increments of 1–2 mm, gradually increase the distance between the two points. Test the subject’s skin after each adjustment. Each time the two points are touched to the skin, ask the test subject whether they feel one point or two distinct points.

Repeat this procedure until the test subject reports feeling two distinct contact points.The measurement at which two distinct points are felt is called the two-point threshold. This value is obtained by reading the number found between the two arrows in the middle of the sliding scale on the two-point discriminator. Record the test subject’s two-point threshold in the “Trial 1” column of Data Table 2.

Repeat Steps 2 and 3, obtaining a two-point threshold measurement for the following areas of the test subject’s body: the palm of the hand, the inside of the forearm, the back of the neck, and the back of the lower leg or calf. Record each of these results in the “Trial 1” column of Data Table 2.
Conduct two additional trials for each location following the procedure described in Steps1–4. Record the results in the “Trial 2” and “Trial 3” columns of Data Table 2.

Using data from the three trials, determine the test subject’s average two-point threshold value at each location. Record this number in the “Average” column of Data Table 2. Analyze the data, and report your conclusions.
In Activity 8, you will conduct temperature sensation tests on the skin of the test subject’s hand (back and palm) and forearm using a metal probe.

Remove the plastic tip cover from the aluminum temperature probe, and place the probe in a cup of ice water [approximately 10° C (50° F)] for a few minutes to allow it to cool. When the probe has cooled, remove it from the cold water and wipe it dry with a paper towel.
The test subject should sit with eyes closed and with the stamped hand motionless on a desk or table with the palm facedown. Begin with the grid on the back of the hand.

In one quadrant of the grid, gently touch each grid space with the temperature probe.The probe should remain on each space for about 2 seconds. The test subject reports whether they feel a cool stimulus. When they feel a stimulus, color in the corresponding space on the appropriate grid in the “Observations” section. Re-cool the probe between quadrants. Continue until all the spaces have been tested.
Note: You are testing for temperature sensation, not for pressure sensitivity. Report a positive response only if a temperature sensation is perceived.

Repeat this procedure for the palm and forearm locations, and record the results in the appropriate grids. Remember that to analyze and interpret the data correctly, the results must be organized, complete, and recorded accurately.

Repeat Steps 1–4 using a warm temperature probe to map warmth receptors. Allow the sensor to warm up in a cup of hot water (between 30–45° C (86–113° F), and repeat the protocol, mapping warmth receptors for the back of the hand, the palm, and the forearm. Rewarm the probe between quadrants.
Caution: Do not use boiling water!  The water should be hot enough to yield a heat sensation from the probe but not so hot to cause injury.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: After you have performed all the experiments, examine the data. Record your conclusions.

text: Discard gloves (if used) in the household trash. Wash your hands whether or not you wore gloves.
Return the materials to your equipment kit.
Sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.text: For all reflex tests other than the plantar reflex, a reflex reaction is muscle contraction. For the plantar reflex, the muscle contraction should result in flexion (i.e., curling) of the toes.

text: Were all reflex tests as expected? Explain your answer.
What did you learn about the receptor densities for the regions you tested based on the data you collected?
Based on these data, what inferences can you make regarding receptor densities and receptive fields? Are some locations more sensitive than others? Explain your answer.

Did you identify a greater number of warm or cold receptor sites? Did different areas register heat and cold differently, and, if so, why do you think this occurred? Were some areas identified as both warmth- and cold-sensitive? Why might this be so?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a motor neuron, showing multiple dendrites and a single axon with a myelin sheath extending from the cell body, branching, and forming neuromuscular junctions with muscle at its terminals
Figure 2: Diagram of signal transmission at a chemical synapse

pageData.content: Figure 3. Cross section of a vertebra and its nervous tissue
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A cross section of the spinal cord with key structures labeled
Figure 4: Diagram showing the parts of a polysynaptic reflex arc activated in response to contact with a hot object, resulting in arm withdrawal

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.  Before starting any activities, you will need to locate a test subject. In Activities 1-5, you will perform five different reflex tests. conduct a stimulus sensitivity test for three different body locations. In Activity 6, you will need to conduct stimulus sensitivity test. 3 body locations tested?  If so, yes go forward if not, no go back. In Activity 7, you will conduct two-point discrimination tests on five locations, for three trials at each location. Then, you will calculate the average two-point threshold value at each location. In Activity 8, you will conduct cold sensation tests on three locations. Then, you will conduct warm sensation tests on three locations.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: The plantar reflex test being performed using the handle of a percussion hammer

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Axon
data.content: Conveys impulses away from the cell body

data.title: Cell body
data.content: Houses the nucleus and most of the organelles (soma)

data.title: Central nervous system (CNS)
data.content: The brain and spinal cord

data.title: Cranial reflex
data.content: Involve the brain and cranial nerves

data.title: Dendrites
data.content: Convey impulses toward the cell body

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Dorsal horn (posterior horn)
data.content: One of the two divisions of the grey matter of the spinal cord

data.title: Dorsal root (posterior root)
data.content: One of the two roots of a spinal nerve

data.title: Dorsal root ganglion
data.content: Enlarged region of the dorsal root adja-cent to the spinal cord

data.title: Ganglia
data.content: Masses of nreves

data.title: Glia
data.content: Provide support for the neurons (called glial cells or neuroglia)

data.title: Gray matter
data.content: The darker tissue of the brain and spinal cord, consisting mainly of made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies; dendrites; and short, unmyelinated axons, together with glia and tiny blood vessels

data.title: Interneurons (association neurons)
data.content: Located between sensory and motor neuron, the most abundant type of neuron

data.title: Monofilament
data.content: A single, synthetic, untwisted filament that is often made of nylon

data.title: Monosynaptic reflex arc
data.content: The afferent neuron synapses directly with the efferent neuron, without an interneuron situated between them

data.title: Motor neuron (efferent neuron)
data.content: Generate impulses that simulate muscle cells to contract, send impulses away from the CNS

data.title: Myelin sheath
data.content: An insulating layer that forms around nerves

data.title: Nerve
data.content: Bundle of fmyelinated axons that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs

data.title: Neuromuscular junction
data.content: Synapses between a motor neuron of the brain or spinal cord and skeletal muscle cells

data.title: Neuron
data.content: Receive and transmit electrochemical signals (nerve impulses)

data.title: Peripheral nervous system (PNS)
data.content: A network of nerves that extend throughout the body

data.title: Polysynaptic reflex arc
data.content: Involves a synapse between an afferent neuron and an interneuron, and an additional synapse between the interneuron and an efferent neuron

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Postsynaptic cell
data.content: A neuron that receives the message

data.title: Presynaptic cell
data.content: A neuron that sends the message

data.title: Receptive field
data.content: The area on the skin that activates a sensory neuron. Receptive fields may be small and numerous or large and overlapping

data.title: Reflex
data.content: Involuntary, practically instantaneous responses to stimuli

data.title: Reflex arc
data.content: The cells involved in generating a reflex reaction

data.title: Sensory neuron (afferent neuron)
data.content: Responsive to sensory stimuli, the direction of the nerve impulses they carry toward the CNS

data.title: Spinal reflex
data.content: Involve the spinal cord and spinal nerves

data.title: Synapse
data.content: The site of transmission of electric nerve impulses between two neurons

data.title: Two-point discrimination test (two-point threshold test)
data.content: The smallest amount of separation between two points touching the skin that produces two distinct sensations of touch

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quad-rupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head

data.title: Ventral horn (anterior horn)
data.content: One of the two divisions of the grey matter of the spinal cord

data.title: Ventral root (anterior root)
data.content: One of the two roots of a spinal nerve

data.title: White matter
data.content: Appears white because the axons are sheathed in a fatty substance, myelin sheath
